## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 156, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 278, 905, 333]]<|/det|>
0606/21 May/June 2017 2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 420, 355]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 437, 375]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Electronic calculator  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 719, 431]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 431, 320, 445]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 445, 504, 460]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 460, 504, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 475, 380, 490]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 282, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 516, 828, 545]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 545, 593, 560]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 559, 603, 574]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 585, 606, 600]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 600, 757, 615]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 615, 437, 630]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 80.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 73, 599, 90]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 164, 561, 182]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 196, 233, 213]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 225, 380, 244]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2} + b x + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 242, 572, 282]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 312, 222, 329]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 333, 751, 371]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n},\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 494, 415]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 481, 594, 499]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 514, 153, 530]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 541, 581, 610]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc \mathrm{e}^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 641, 235, 658]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 664, 591, 696]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 715, 593, 770]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\] \[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 96, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 925, 102]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the curve which passes through the point (2, 17) and for which \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = 4x^3 + 1\). [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 329, 447, 350]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 352, 824, 386]]<|/det|>

<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Four cinemas, \(P\), \(Q\), \(R\) and \(S\) each sell adult, student and child tickets. The number of tickets sold by each cinema on one weekday were

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 102, 598, 121]]<|/det|>
\[P\colon 90 \text{ adult, } 10 \text{ student, } 30 \text{ child}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 119, 455, 136]]<|/det|>
\(Q\): 45 student

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 133, 512, 152]]<|/det|>
\(R\): 25 adult, 15 child

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 149, 520, 166]]<|/det|>
\(S\): 10 adult, 100 child.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 178, 143, 197]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 178, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathbf{L} = (1 \quad 1 \quad 1 \quad 1)\), construct a matrix, \(\mathbf{M}\), of the number of tickets sold, such that the matrix product \(\mathbf{LM}\) can be found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 198, 920, 215]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 345, 143, 364]]<|/det|>

<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 547, 141, 566]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 546, 662, 566]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 546, 920, 565]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 666, 710, 686]]<|/det|>
An adult ticket costs \(\)5,\(a student ticket costs\)\\(4\) and a child ticket costs \(\)3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 698, 141, 715]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 696, 920, 732]]<|/det|>

<label>7</label>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 71, 821, 92]]<|/det|>
On each of the Venn diagrams below shade the region which represents the given set.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 102, 839, 293]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 327, 144, 346]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 327, 920, 362]]<|/det|>
In a group of students, each student studies at most two of art, music and design. No student studies both music and design.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 374, 532, 393]]<|/det|>
\(A\) denotes the set of students who study art,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 388, 564, 408]]<|/det|>
\(M\) denotes the set of students who study music,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 403, 564, 422]]<|/det|>
\(D\) denotes the set of students who study design.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 435, 181, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 435, 497, 454]]<|/det|>
Write the following using set notation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 466, 591, 485]]<|/det|>
No student studies both music and design.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 466, 920, 485]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 558, 920, 593]]<|/det|>
There are 100 students in the group. 39 students study art, 45 study music and 36 study design. 12 students study both art and music. 25 students study both art and design.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 605, 180, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 605, 920, 640]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 650, 567, 819]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 836, 920, 856]]<|/det|>

<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A football club has 30 players. In how many different ways can a captain and a vice-captain be selected at random from these players?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 104]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
A team of 11 teachers is to be chosen from 2 mathematics teachers, 5 computing teachers and 9 science teachers. Find the number of different teams that can be chosen if

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 180, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 241, 591, 259]]<|/det|>
the team must have exactly 1 mathematics teacher,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 241, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 465, 181, 483]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 465, 855, 483]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 464, 920, 483]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 855, 95]]<|/det|>

\(P\)4.398.3315.830.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 168, 144, 186]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 166, 554, 186]]<|/det|> Draw the graph of \(\ln P\) against \(t\) on the grid below. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 168, 920, 186]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 198, 809, 481]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 494, 141, 512]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 494, 583, 512]]<|/det|> Use the graph to estimate the value of \(P\) when \(t = 2.2\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 494, 920, 512]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 560, 141, 579]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 560, 920, 594]]<|/det|> Find the gradient of the graph and state the coordinates of the point where the graph meets the vertical axis. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 577, 920, 594]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 660, 141, 677]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 658, 923, 677]]<|/det|> Using your answers to part **(iii)**, show that \(P = ab^{t}\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants to be found. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[910, 658, 923, 677]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 777, 143, 794]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 775, 920, 810]]<|/det|> Given that your equation in part **(iv)** is valid for values of \(t\) up to 10, find the smallest value of \(t\), correct to 1 decimal place, for which \(P\) is at least 1000. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 789, 920, 808]]<|/det|> [2]
